question: Почему золото так ценно? И почему оно ценнее других металлов, например, серебра?
model_answer:
Добрый день! Золото - это редкий и ценный металл, который ценится за его уникальные свойства и исторические значения. Вот несколько причин, почему золото так ценно:

1. Редкость: Золото является относительно редким металлом, что делает его более ценным. В природе золото встречается в небольших количествах, что ограничивает его производство и делает его более дорогим.
2. Коррозионная стойкость: Золото имеет высокую коррозионную стойкость, что означает, что оно не корродирует и не разлагается в присутствии воздуха, воды или других химических веществ. Это делает его идеальным материалом для использования в ювелирном деле и других приложениях, где требуются высокие стандарты качества.
3. Электрические свойства: Золото имеет высокую электропроводимость, что делает его идеальным материалом для использования в электронике и электротехнике.
4. История и символизм: Золото имеет богатую историю и символизм. В древности золото использовалось как символ богатства, власти и статуса, и это значение сохранилось до сих пор.
5. Внешний вид: Золото имеет красивый блестящий вид, что делает его привлекательным для использования в ювелирном деле и других приложениях, где внешний вид важен.

В сравнении с серебром, золото имеет несколько преимуществ:

* Золото имеет более высокую плотность, что делает его более тяжелым и более дорогим.
* Золото имеет более высокую электропроводимость, что делает его более подходящим для использования в электронике и электротехнике.
* Золото имеет более высокую коррозионную стойкость, что делает его более подходящим для использования в приложениях, где требуются высокие стандарты качества.

В целом, золото является уникальным металлом, который ценится за его редкость, коррозионную стойкость, электрические свойства, историю и символ
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Russian. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Russian:
5,000 years ago humans didn't know much about metal, metalworking, geology, or mining. But they did have a sense for fashion.
Most metals exist naturally as rock. The metal atoms are connected to other kinds of elements like silicon and they don't look very interesting (to a non-geologist). In the world before the Bronze Age, the only metals most humans would recognize were silver and gold.
Gold can be found as "nuggets" or "dust". The processes that bring it to the surface tends to deposit it in veins so that if you find some, you're likely to find more. Typically it is exposed by weather and flushed downhill into rivers, so finding gold means finding a river with some gold or silver in it, and then looking for more - you don't have to mine it.
You can work gold without heat. It is "malleable" at room temperature, which means you can whack on it with hammers to change the shape of a lump of gold and bend it with tongs - and even though it is malleable it won't lose its new shape once you finish working it and that means you can make useful things.
Gold will not hold an edge so it is useless as a blade. It is much denser than most other materials so it would make a good club, but you don't get much more head-bashing advantage with a gold cub than you would with stone or even wood. So other than as jewelry and as decoration, gold has little practical "use" to an ancient human.
But it is pretty. Aesthetically gold looks "good" next to human skin tones. Why this is so is pretty much a mystery. But it's obvious that people found gold attractive very very early in human development.
Who gets jewelry? Rich people. In the ancient world "rich" was defined as "don't have to farm". There were only three kinds of people like that: royalty, high priests, and successful generals.
Since gold was in limited supply - but there was enough of it that people would recognize it and value it, and it wasn't good for any practical use, and as a metal it would "stay all in one place" and didn't have to be kept in jars or otherwise contained, it became a way for rich people to display their wealth.
Gold is pretty easy to purify and to determine purity (it's a simple weight/volume calculation). That means that it could be exchanged between people for like value - a fixed amount of gold, of a certain purity, was "worth" some number of sheep or sheaves of wheat, or slaves, or land, or whatever. It became a unit of currency due to intrinsic properties convenient for anyone to access - all I need is a scale, a cup, some water, and a little math and I can figure out how much your gold is worth to me.
5,000 years of humans accepting gold as valuable has imbued it with a certain advantage vs. other similar metals. Nobody wants to exchange plutonium coins, even though plutonium is worth, ounce for ounce, vastly more than gold. Gold turns out to have practical uses for modern humans that ancient humans didn't know about - it's an extraordinarily good conductor of electricity. And it still looks good next to human skin.

ground_truth:
5,000 years ago humans didn't know much about metal, metalworking, geology, or mining. But they did have a sense for fashion.
Most metals exist naturally as rock. The metal atoms are connected to other kinds of elements like silicon and they don't look very interesting (to a non-geologist). In the world before the Bronze Age, the only metals most humans would recognize were silver and gold.
Gold can be found as "nuggets" or "dust". The processes that bring it to the surface tends to deposit it in veins so that if you find some, you're likely to find more. Typically it is exposed by weather and flushed downhill into rivers, so finding gold means finding a river with some gold or silver in it, and then looking for more - you don't have to mine it.
You can work gold without heat. It is "malleable" at room temperature, which means you can whack on it with hammers to change the shape of a lump of gold and bend it with tongs - and even though it is malleable it won't lose its new shape once you finish working it and that means you can make useful things.
Gold will not hold an edge so it is useless as a blade. It is much denser than most other materials so it would make a good club, but you don't get much more head-bashing advantage with a gold cub than you would with stone or even wood. So other than as jewelry and as decoration, gold has little practical "use" to an ancient human.
But it is pretty. Aesthetically gold looks "good" next to human skin tones. Why this is so is pretty much a mystery. But it's obvious that people found gold attractive very very early in human development.
Who gets jewelry? Rich people. In the ancient world "rich" was defined as "don't have to farm". There were only three kinds of people like that: royalty, high priests, and successful generals.
Since gold was in limited supply - but there was enough of it that people would recognize it and value it, and it wasn't good for any practical use, and as a metal it would "stay all in one place" and didn't have to be kept in jars or otherwise contained, it became a way for rich people to display their wealth.
Gold is pretty easy to purify and to determine purity (it's a simple weight/volume calculation). That means that it could be exchanged between people for like

question: Как учёные определяют температуру ядра Земли?
model_answer:
Отличный вопрос!

Учёные определяют температуру ядра Земли с помощью различных методов, включая:

1. Сейсмические измерения: при землетрясении происходит изменение температуры ядра Земли, которое можно измерить с помощью сейсмических станций.
2. Методы нейтронной томографии: учёные используют нейтроны, которые проходят через ядро Земли и измеряют изменение их скорости, что позволяет определить температуру.
3. Методы гравиметрии: изменение гравитационного поля Земли, вызванное изменением температуры ядра, измеряется с помощью гравиметрических станций.
4. Методы магнитометрии: изменение магнитного поля Земли, вызванное изменением температуры ядра, измеряется с помощью магнитометрических станций.
5. Методы термальной томографии: учёные используют тепловые лучи, которые проходят через ядро Земли и измеряют изменение их интенсивности, что позволяет определить температуру.

Согласно данным, полученным с помощью этих методов, температура ядра Земли оценивается в диапазоне от 5 000 до 6 000 градусов по Цельсию (4 727 до 5 727 градусов по Фаренгейту). Это значительно выше температуры поверхности Земли, которая составляет около 15 градусов по Цельсию (59 градусов по Фаренгейту).

question: Почему бег перед прыжком помогает нам прыгать выше?
model_answer:
Отличный вопрос!

Бег перед прыжком, также известный как "run-up" или "approach", действительно помогает нам прыгать выше. Это потому, что бег создает дополнительную энергию и импульс, который мы можем использовать для увеличения высоты прыжка.

Когда мы бежим, мы создаем потенциальную энергию, которая хранится в наших мышцах и суставах. Затем, когда мы прыгаем, мы используем эту энергию для преодоления силы тяжести и увеличения высоты прыжка.

Бег перед прыжком помогает в следующих способах:

1. Увеличивает силу и мощь прыжка: бег создает дополнительную силу, которая помогает нам преодолевать силу тяжести и прыгать выше.
2. Улучшает координацию и равновесие: бег помогает нам развивать координацию и равновесие, что позволяет нам лучше контролировать свой прыжок и прыгать более высоко.
3. Увеличивает длину прыжка: бег позволяет нам создавать дополнительную длину прыжка, что также помогает нам прыгать выше.

В целом, бег перед прыжком - это важный компонент для улучшения нашей прыжковой способности и достижения более высоких результатов в различных видах спорта, таких как футбол, баскетбол, волейбол и другие.

question: Почему у бегунов пульс ниже, чем у тех, кто не занимается бегом?
model_answer:
Хорошая вопрос! 

У бегунов пульс ниже, чем у тех, кто не занимается бегом, из-за адаптации сердечно-сосудистой системы к физической нагрузке. Когда человек занимается бегом, его сердце начинает работать более эффективно, чтобы обеспечить доставку кислорода и питательных веществ к мышцам.

В результате, сердце у бегунов развивается более мощное и эластичное, что позволяет им иметь более низкий пульс, даже при выполнении физической нагрузки. Это происходит из-за следующих факторов:

1. Увеличение сердечной массы: бегунство вызывает увеличение массы сердца, что позволяет сердцу помочь в доставке крови к мышцам.
2. Увеличение эластичности сосудов: бегунство улучшает эластичность сосудов, что позволяет им расширяться и сужаться более эффективно, что уменьшает нагрузку на сердце.
3. Увеличение кровотока: бегунство улучшает кровоток, что позволяет сердцу доставлять больше крови к мышцам, что уменьшает пульс.
4. Увеличение функции левого желудочка: бегунство улучшает функцию левого желудочка сердца, что позволяет сердцу помочь в доставке крови к мышцам.

Таким образом, у бегунов пульс ниже, чем у тех, кто не занимается бегом, из-за адаптации сердечно-сосудистой системы к физической нагрузке.

Наконец, четвертое объяснение связано с изменением уровня физиологической готовности организма к физической нагрузке. There’s many reasons but the main 3 are security features, device compatibility, and new things being added.
The big one (and reason to regularly update) is security. Imagine securing software like trying to make a door that only you can walk through. After you use it enough times, other people trying to also walk through that door (steal your data, personal info, or financial info) might pick up on patterns and think of ways of keeping the door propped open, messing with the locks, etc. Security updates close these loopholes and keep the door only opening for you.
Another one is new devices. An app might’ve been written for the iPhone X but a few years later we’re now on the iPhone 15 with a completely different operating system and features that didn’t exist when the app was written. It needs to know how to recognize and interact with that new OS (and any future updates to the OS) or it could introduce bugs and crash the app.
Finally, and most straight forward, is them adding new stuff to the software. As people use something they provide feedback and the company uses updates to add that feedback into the software.

question: ¿Por qué no pueden regenerarse los huesos?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta! Los huesos son tejidos complejos que están diseñados para ser fuertes y resistentes, pero no pueden regenerarse exactamente como otros tejidos del cuerpo, como la piel o los músculos. Hay varias razones por las que los huesos no pueden regenerarse de la misma manera:

1. La estructura: Los huesos están compuestos por células óseas, hueso compacto y hueso esponjoso, que están unidos por una matriz de colágeno y minerales. Esta estructura compleja no se puede regenerar de la misma manera que otros tejidos.
2. La función: Los huesos tienen una función estructural y protectora, y su forma y tamaño son críticos para el movimiento y la estabilidad del cuerpo. La regeneración de huesos tendría que ser muy precisa para mantener la función óptima.
3. La falta de células madre óseas: Las células madre óseas son las responsables de la formación y reparación de los huesos. Sin embargo, estas células no son tan abundantes como las células madre de otros tejidos, lo que limita la capacidad de regeneración ósea.
4. La influencia de factores genéticos: La capacidad de regeneración ósea puede ser influenciada por factores genéticos, lo que puede afectar la capacidad de los huesos para regenerarse.

Aunque los huesos no pueden regenerarse exactamente como otros tejidos, hay tratamientos y terapias que pueden ayudar a reparar y fortalecer los huesos, como la terapia de estimulación ósea, la terapia de crecimiento óseo y la injerto óseo. Sin embargo, estos tratamientos no pueden regenerar huesos dañados o deteriorados de manera completa.

question: ¿Por qué necesitamos actualizar constantemente el software? ¿Qué pasa si no lo hago?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta! Actualizar el software es importante porque los desarrolladores de software suelen corregir errores, mejorar la seguridad y agregar nuevas características y mejoras constantemente. Si no actualizas el software, puedes enfrentar varios problemas:

1. **Seguridad**: Los hackers pueden encontrar vulnerabilidades en versiones antiguas del software y explotarlas para acceder a tus datos personales o comprometer la integridad de tu sistema.
2. **Funcionalidades**: Las nuevas versiones del software suelen incluir mejoras y actualizaciones de características que pueden mejorar tu experiencia de usuario. Si no actualizas, podrías perder acceso a funciones importantes o no poder utilizar nuevas herramientas.
3. **Compatibilidad**: Los desarrolladores pueden dejar de soportar versiones antiguas del software, lo que significa que podrías dejar de recibir actualizaciones y soporte técnico.
4. **Riesgos de incompatibilidad**: Si no actualizas, es posible que el software no se adapte correctamente a nuevos sistemas operativos, hardware o dispositivos, lo que podría causar problemas de compatibilidad.
5. **Desarrollo de bugs**: Las versiones antiguas del software pueden contener bugs y errores que no se han resuelto, lo que podría causar problemas y errores frecuentes.

En resumen, actualizar el software es importante para mantener la seguridad, mejorar la experiencia de usuario y asegurarte de que el software siga funcionando correctamente con nuevos sistemas y dispositivos.

Es importante mencionar que, en algunos casos, no actualizar el software puede no ser un problema inmediato, pero es importante tener en cuenta que la seguridad y la compatibilidad pueden ser comprometidas en el futuro. Es recomendable actualizar el software regularmente para mantener tu sistema seguro y actualizado.

There’s many reasons but the main 3 are security features, device compatibility, and new things being added.
The big one (and reason to regularly update) is security. Imagine securing software like trying to make a door that only you can walk through. After you use it enough times, other people trying to also walk through that door (steal your data, personal info, or financial info) might pick up on patterns and think of ways of keeping the door propped open, messing with the locks, etc. Security updates close these loopholes and keep the door only opening for you.
Another one is new devices. An app might’ve been written for the iPhone X but a few years later we’re now on the iPhone 15 with a completely different operating system and features that didn’t exist when the app was written. It needs to know how to recognize and interact with that new OS (and any future updates to the OS) or it could introduce bugs and crash the app.
Finally, and most straight forward, is them adding new stuff to the software. As people use something they provide feedback and the company uses updates to add that feedback into the software.

question: ¿Cuál es la ciencia detrás de la parálisis del sueño?
model_answer:
La parálisis del sueño, también conocida como parálisis nocturna del sueño (PNS), es un fenómeno neurológico que ocurre cuando una persona se encuentra en un estado de sueño profundo, pero su cuerpo permanece paralizado y no puede moverse. A continuación, te explico la ciencia detrás de esta condición:

La parálisis del sueño se produce cuando el cerebro entra en un estado de sueño REM (rapid eye movement), que es el tipo de sueño en el que se experimentan los sueños vívidos y la actividad cerebral es similar a la despertar. Durante este estado, el cerebro produce una sustancia química llamada atropina, que inhibe los mensajes nerviosos que controlan los músculos, lo que impide que el cuerpo se mueva.

La parálisis del sueño se cree que se debe a la interacción entre dos sistemas cerebrales:

1. El sistema de sueño: Regula el ciclo de sueño-vigilia y controla la profundidad del sueño. Durante el sueño REM, el sistema de sueño activa la parálisis muscular para evitar que el cuerpo se mueva y cause daños a sí mismo o a los demás.
2. El sistema de alerta: Regula la alerta y la atención. Durante el sueño REM, el sistema de alerta se activa para mantener el cuerpo paralizado y evitar que se mueva accidentalmente.

La parálisis del sueño puede ser causada por varios factores, como:

* La falta de sueño o la sobrecarga de sueño
* El estrés y la ansiedad
* La depresión y la ansiedad
* La medicación y los fármacos
* La enfermedad neurológica, como la enfermedad de Parkinson o la esclerosis múltiple

En general, la parálisis del sueño es un fenómeno normal y no es una condición médica grave. Sin embargo, en algunos casos, puede ser un síntoma de una condición médica subyacente que requiere atención médica.

When you fall asleep, your brain paralyzes your body to prevent you from physically acting out your dreams and injuring yourself somehow.
This function isn't perfect though. Sometimes it fails to kick in, which is what sleepwalking is, and other times it kicks in early and paralyzes you before you're actually fully asleep.
So, still being kind of awake, the parts of your brain that go dormant during sleep are still active enough to realize that you're paralyzed. Often times though, you're 'asleep' enough to start dreaming.
So what you can get is dreaming while awake but paralyzed. Most people freak out when they realize they're paralyzed, and that can fuel nightmares, so you get people's dreams telling them that there's some kind of monster holding them down to explain their inability to move. Hence the whole "Sleep Paralysis Demon" thing you hear people talk about.

question: ¿Cuál es la función del sueño?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta! El sueño es un proceso natural del cuerpo que cumple varias funciones importantes para nuestra salud y bienestar. Algunas de las funciones del sueño son:

1. **Reconstrucción y reparación**: Durante el sueño, nuestro cuerpo reparara y reconstruye tejidos y órganos dañados, lo que ayuda a mantener nuestra salud general.
2. **Eliminación de residuos**: El sueño ayuda a eliminar residuos tóxicos y productos químicos del cerebro, lo que puede ayudar a prevenir enfermedades como la demencia y la depresión.
3. **Consolidación de memoria**: El sueño es importante para la consolidación de la memoria y la formación de nuevos recuerdos. Durante el sueño, el cerebro procesa y organiza la información que hemos aprendido durante el día.
4. **Regulación del estrés**: El sueño ayuda a regular el estrés y la ansiedad, lo que puede reducir el riesgo de enfermedades como la hipertensión y el infarto de miocardio.
5. **Regulación del metabolismo**: El sueño afecta la regulación del metabolismo, lo que puede ayudar a controlar el peso y la glucemia.
6. **Regulación del sistema inmunológico**: El sueño es importante para la regulación del sistema inmunológico, lo que puede ayudar a prevenir enfermedades infecciosas.
7. **Regulación del crecimiento y desarrollo**: El sueño es importante para el crecimiento y desarrollo en niños y adolescentes, ya que ayuda a regular la secreción de hormonas que controlan el crecimiento.

En resumen, el sueño es esencial para nuestra salud y bienestar, y es importante que intentemos dormir lo suficiente cada noche para aprovechar todas sus beneficios.

question: ¿Cómo se sabe el porcentaje de grasa corporal de una persona, o es algo que simplemente se estima?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta! El porcentaje de grasa corporal (PC) se puede medir de varias maneras, y no es algo que se estime simplemente. A continuación, te presento algunas de las formas más comunes de medir el PC:

1. **Medición antropométrica**: Se mide la circunferencia de la cintura y la circunferencia de la cadera. Luego, se calcula el índice de masa corporal (IMC) y se aplica una fórmula para determinar el PC. Esta método es relativamente preciso, pero puede variar dependiendo de la técnica utilizada y la precisión de las mediciones.
2. **Bioimpedancia**: Se utiliza un dispositivo de bioimpedancia para medir la resistencia eléctrica del cuerpo. La resistencia es mayor en los músculos y menor en la grasa. El dispositivo calcula el PC basándose en la resistencia y la reactancia. Este método es más preciso que la medición antropométrica y se utiliza comúnmente en clínicas y centros de fitness.
3. **Densitometría**: Se utiliza un equipo de densitometría para medir la densidad ósea y la masa muscular. La densidad ósea es mayor en los huesos y menor en la grasa. El equipo calcula el PC basándose en la densidad y la masa corporal. Este método es considerado el más preciso, pero es más costoso y no es comúnmente disponible en clínicas y centros de fitness.
4. **Análisis de la composición corporal**: Se utiliza un equipo de análisis de la composición corporal que mide la cantidad de grasa y masa muscular en el cuerpo. Este método es similar a la densitometría, pero es más preciso y comúnmente disponible en clínicas y centros de fitness.

En resumen, el porcentaje de grasa corporal se puede medir de varias maneras, y cada método tiene sus propias ventajas y desventajas. La medición antropométrica es una forma relativamente barata y fácil de realizar, mientras que la bioimpedancia y la densitometría son más precisas pero también más costosas. El análisis de la composición corporal es considerado

old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Tongan. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tongan:
That's not entirely true
TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited) is one of the premiere chip manufacturing companies in the world but they are hardly the only one.
They are of note because they make everything from common chips used in everything from cars to cellphones to AMDs processors. Apple, Nvidia, AMD, and Qualcomm for example all use TSMC to manufacture their chips.
But Samsung (Korea) and Intel (US) also have chip foundries of that caliber.
TSMCs secret is just that they have large numbers of highly experienced people working for them and have developed very good processes. Samsung and Intel are similar in that regard, but TSMC is special in that the Taiwanese government has in a sense made semiconductor manufacturing the countries primary industry.
Other companies like Texas instruments can also make microchips and have facilities all over the US but can't make chips as complex as Computer microprocessors. Importantly though there's nothing stopping them from investing capital to build such a facility, they just don't want to. (Developing an in house microprocessor to compete with AMD and Intel at this point would require an outrageous investment)
Israel is also another big up and comer in chip manufacturing.
Why TSMC is of note is the Pandemic showed just how vulnerable the US and the West are to losing access to TSMC production. If China for example were to invade Taiwan it could be a really big problem for the economy and availability of these chips.
This is why TSMC is building a Chip Foundry in Texas Arizona right now so chip production can happen domestically in the US.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tswana:
There’s many reasons but the main 3 are security features, device compatibility, and new things being added.
The big one (and reason to regularly update) is security. Imagine securing software like trying to make a door that only you can walk through. After you use it enough times, other people trying to also walk through that door (steal your data, personal info, or financial info) might pick up on patterns and think of ways of keeping the door propped open, messing with the locks, etc. Security updates close these loopholes and keep the door only opening for you.
Another one is new devices. An app might’ve been written for the iPhone X but a few years later we’re now on the iPhone 15 with a completely different operating system and features that didn’t exist when the app was written. It needs to know how to recognize and interact with that new OS (and any future updates to the OS) or it could introduce bugs and crash the app.
Finally, and most straight forward, is them adding new stuff to the software. As people use something they provide feedback and the company uses updates to add that feedback into the software.

Translate the following question from English into Tswana. Make it sound as natural as possible:
Why do we need to constantly do software updates? What happens if I don't?

There are a few places where the blood vessels have to come right under the skin though. The elbow is one of these places. model_answer: Ke ka ntlha yang fa gauta e le botlhokwa jaana, ke ka ntlha yang fa e le botlhokwa go feta dimetale tse dingwe, jaaka selefera. Ke ka ntlha yang fa gauta e le botlhokwa jaana, ke ka ntlha yang fa e le botlhokwa go feta dimetale tse dingwe, jaaka selefera.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Tswana. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tswana:
5,000 years ago humans didn't know much about metal, metalworking, geology, or mining. But they did have a sense for fashion.
Most metals exist naturally as rock. The metal atoms are connected to other kinds of elements like silicon and they don't look very interesting (to a non-geologist). In the world before the Bronze Age, the only metals most humans would recognize were silver and gold.
Gold can be found as "nuggets" or "dust". The processes that bring it to the surface tends to deposit it in veins so that if you find some, you're likely to find more. Typically it is exposed by weather and flushed downhill into rivers, so finding gold means finding a river with some gold or silver in it, and then looking for more - you don't have to mine it.
You can work gold without heat. It is "malleable" at room temperature, which means you can whack on it with hammers to change the shape of a lump of gold and bend it with tongs - and even though it is malleable it won't lose its new shape once you finish working it and that means you can make useful things.
Gold will not hold an edge so it is useless as a blade. It is much denser than most other materials so it would make a good club, but you don't get much more head-bashing advantage with a gold cub than you would with stone or even wood. So other than as jewelry and as decoration, gold has little practical "use" to an ancient human.
But it is pretty. Aesthetically gold looks "good" next to human skin tones. Why this is so is pretty much a mystery. But it's obvious that people found gold attractive very very early in human development.
Who gets jewelry? Rich people. In the ancient world "rich" was defined as "don't have to farm". There were only three kinds of people like that: royalty, high priests, and successful generals.
Since gold was in limited supply - but there was enough of it that people would recognize it and value it, and it wasn't good for any practical use, and as a metal it would "stay all in one place" and didn't have to be kept in jars or otherwise contained, it became a way for rich people to display their wealth.
Gold is pretty easy to purify and to determine purity (it's a simple weight/volume calculation). That means that it could be exchanged between people for like value - a fixed amount of gold, of a certain purity, was "worth" some number of sheep or sheaves of wheat, or slaves, or land, or whatever. It became a unit of currency due to intrinsic properties convenient for anyone to access - all I need is a scale, a cup, some water, and a little math and I can figure out how much your gold is worth to me.
5,000 years of humans accepting gold as valuable has imbued it with a certain advantage vs. other similar metals. Nobody wants to exchange plutonium coins, even though plutonium is worth, ounce for ounce, vastly more than gold. Gold turns out to have practical uses for modern humans that ancient humans didn't know about - it's an extraordinarily good conductor of electricity. And it still looks good next to human skin.

Translate the following question from English into Tswana. Make it sound as natural as possible:
Why is gold so valuable? And why is it more valuable than other metals, like silver?

question: Ke ka ntlha yang fa go le motlhofo go leka-lekana mo sethuthuthung fa se ntse se tsamaya mme go le thata thata fa se eme fela?
model_answer: Ke go tshwenyeha! Ke go tlhokomediwa ke go le motlhofo go leka-lekana mo sethuthuthung fa se ntse se tsamaya mme go le thata thata fa se eme fela. Ke go tlhokomediwa ke go le motlhofo go leka-lekana mo sethuthuthung fa se ntse se tsamaya mme go le thata thata fa se eme fela.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Tswana. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tswana:
Bicycle (and motorcycle) dynamics are very complex. Physicists and mathematicians have been having trouble modeling exactly what makes two wheeled vehicles stable. Here's one stab at it.
Some things are known to increase stability. The gyroscopic effect of the wheels plays a minor role. As /u/bjujey pointed out below, experiments have shown that removing the gyroscopic effect still makes for a stable bike.
Trail also plays a role. Trail is the measurement of where the steering axis in relation to the contact of the wheel on the ground. Here's a picture for illustration. This is also called the caster effect. Basically the further forward the steering axis is from wheel contact with the ground, the more stable the bike. Track bikes and cyclocross bikes have really short trail to make them more agile. Big stable cruisers have long trails.
Like gyroscopic effect, experiments have removed trail as a variable and these models are also stable. Here is an interview with a scientist who removed both gyroscopic and caster/trail effects in a model bicycle, and it remained stable.
tl;dr: No one really knows what makes a moving bike stable.
Edit: I guess I should mention it is possible to be stabilize a non-moving bike in a technique called a trackstand. Here's two track racers doing it on fixed gear bikes. Its a bit more complicated but still possible on bikes with a freewheel or freehub.

Translate the following question from English into Tswana. Make it sound as natural as possible:
Why is it easy to balance on a bicycle when it is moving but nearly impossible when it is stationary?

question: Ci sunu yaram wi, faaydaale cell yi am nañu. Lu tax bët yi diiwaan?
model_answer: Asalama! Ci sunu yaram wi, faaydaale cell yi am nañu. Lu tax bët yi diiwaan, ci yoonu yor, ci yoonu yor, ci yoonu yor! (Hello! How are you, my friend? How are you, my friend, how are you, my friend!)
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Wolof. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Wolof:
Neurons in your brain would need to be both able to replace themselves, and then most importantly, spread their axons and dendrites to the appropriate location. Brain cells are a small cell body coupled with long tentacle like structures that stretch from place to place to form connections. This means that in a place like your spine, a single cell goes all the way from your brain to your tailbone, which means that the cell is about a meter long! Its easy enough for a new cell body to be put in the same place if the original gets damaged, but it would be very hard to make sure that cell then grew that extreme distance and connected back to the correct target.
There are some animals that have very impressive regenerative properties, but it just isn't something humans (or most mammals) are capable of. In the ancestral environment, an accident that was bad enough to leave you paralyzed was generally bad enough to kill you pretty quickly, which means that we never evolved a way to regenerate that kind of damage.
